A $110 million settlement between Warner Music and Bertelsmann resolves claims that Bertelsmann had contributed to widespread copyright infringement.

The Warner Music Group, the recording company, said yesterday that it would receive $110 million as part of a settlement with Bertelsmann, the German media giant, that resolves claims that Bertelsmann had contributed to widespread copyright infringement by supporting Napster, the file-sharing service.
Under the settlement with Warner Music, Bertelsmann will admit no liability.

Bertelsmann provided Napster with about $85 million in loans starting in late 2000, a time when Napster had enabled millions of users to trade pirated songs online. (Napster has since been reinvented as a licensed subscription service).

The settlement comes a month after Bertelsmann reached a similar agreement with the EMI Group, the British music giant. Last year, Bertelsmann also agreed to pay about $60 million to resolve claims by the Universal Music Group, the world's biggest music corporation. That settlement was part of Universal's arrangement to buy Bertelsmann's music publishing unit for $2 billion.

The agreement is the latest in a bitter chapter for the music industry, which has long sought redress for the havoc unleashed by Napster in 1999. After swapping music files online turned into a mass phenomenon, sales of recorded music plunged. While the industry has won several legal victories, it has been unable to reverse the slide.
